events.title: First Use of a Transcontinental Telegraph
events.description: The first transcontinental telegraph line was completed, allowing rapid communication across the United States from coast to coast.
events.significance: This event marked the end of the Pony Express and revolutionized communication, enabling instant transmission of messages across vast distances.

events.title: Opening of the Eiffel Tower
events.description: The Eiffel Tower officially opened to the public during the 1889 Exposition Universelle in Paris, France.
events.significance: A symbol of modern engineering and French ingenuity, the Eiffel Tower became an iconic landmark and a cultural symbol of France.

events.title: Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire
events.description: A devastating fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory in New York City killed 146 garment workers, mostly young immigrant women.
events.significance: The tragedy led to significant reforms in workplace safety and labor laws, improving conditions for industrial workers.

events.title: South Africa Withdraws from the Commonwealth
events.description: Following a whites-only referendum, South Africa declared itself a republic and withdrew from the British Commonwealth.
events.significance: This marked South Africa's increasing international isolation due to its policy of apartheid, affecting global relations.

events.title: Death of Michael Jackson
events.description: Michael Jackson, the 'King of Pop,' died unexpectedly at age 50 in Los Angeles, California.
events.significance: His death marked the end of an era in pop music and led to global mourning and renewed interest in his musical legacy.
